Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\) where \\( x(t) \\) and \\( y(t) \\) are real-valued functions evolving over time according to the system \\(\\frac{d}{dt}z(t) = Pz(t)\\), with P being a constant matrix. We investigate the effect of a linear transformation \\( g(z) = Qz \\), where Q is also a constant matrix.

If the transformation \\( g(z) \\) is applied to \\( z_0 \\) at t = 0 and then allowed to evolve under \\(\\frac{d}{dt}z = Pz\\) without further intervention, will the state \\( z(T) \\) at T be identical to evolving \\( z_0 \\) under \\(\\frac{d}{dt}z = Pz\\) to T without applying \\( g(z) \\)?
Explanation: Applying the transformation \\( g(z) = Qz \\) at the outset modifies the initial conditions. Depending on the nature of Q relative to P, this can change the trajectory in the complex plane, resulting in a different state at time T.
